title: Stunning
content: REVIEWED BY SUNNY
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 1, 2013

title: Verified Purchase
content: HOME FRONT starts by giving us a look back at how Jolene Zarkades grew up, so we can understand who she becomes. This important glimpse into the heroine's early life provides a meaningful backstory that was critical for the development of this main character. Most of the story revolves around the evolution of Jolene and those that fill her life. She is married to Michael, has two daughters, Betsy (12) and Lulu (4), and a best friend, Tami. She is a wife, a mother, and a dutiful helicopter pilot for the Army National Guard. Kristin Hannah weaves these people and these roles into a beautiful story about a family just trying to survive all that life throws their way.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2024

title: A great read that will stick with me!
content: It took me some time to get into this book. I was frustrated with the pace of the story at first. What I understood later was the importance of all the early events. They created the full picture of how the characters were in pre-deployment life, and how it was different for them post-deployment. The news of Jolene being deployed is when this story really started picking up. Imagine being pretty much a full-time mother, then getting the directive to start putting your affairs in order. Hannah did such a beautiful job of writing Jolene's transition. She began writing things down to prepare her husband for the day to day, and more importantly, preparing her family for life without her. As a woman helicopter pilot, she told those she loved that she wouldn't be in harm's way, yet she created beautiful videos for her daughters, just in case leaving was her final goodbye. I was emotionally touched by the circumstances and suddenly overwhelmed that soldiers across the country are preparing their own videos every day and saying goodbyes to protect our freedoms.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on February 13, 2012

title: Verified Purchase
content: Things were difficult for everyone once Jolene left. Everyone was just trying to survive the circumstances and all of the new challenges at war and at home. This was when another special transition in the book occurred. Jolene protects her family from the truth while documenting actual events of war in a personal journal. A subplot for Michael has him defending a soldier, which provides him with clarity of Jolene's situation. This allows his character to develop into who he needs to be to support his post-deployment family.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 5, 2024

title: So real ;-)
content: All characters grow substantially in HOME FRONT. Oddly, I felt like and dislike for pretty much every character in the book at one time or another. At times, I was frustrated by the selfishness, the naiveté, the cowardice. Then I would be shockingly reminded of the reasons for those actions/feelings. Kristin Hannah plots out her storylines and characters well to weave a special story. The post-deployment life of the Zarkades family is another challenge that is beautifully written. How this family comes back together and starts healing is wonderful.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 8, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I can't say that I have much personal experience with this storyline as none of my close family or friends have ever gone to war. This book was truly an eye opener for me, and even though I had the utmost respect for our soldiers before, I had no idea what going to war was like. After getting a look into the life of a frontline soldier, it made me appreciate even more all who have fought for our freedoms. I am ashamed to say I wouldn't have the strength it must take to do what so many soldiers have. I am thankful to have read HOME FRONT to gain a better understanding of a soldier's sacrifice as well as the sacrifices of the family left behind. This story will stick with me for a long time!
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2024

title: Brought me back 19 years
content: I read a lot. A book or two a week. This is the first book review I’ve ever written. In 2005 my husband deployed to Iraq leaving me and our two children 5 and 8 for 15 months. I’m a teacher, structured and organized,  much like Jolene early in the book. I was sure that we’d get through it without a hitch. Boy was I wrong.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 16, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This book brought me right back. I’m a huge Kristin Hanna fan but I was reluctant to read this book. She’s a master story teller and this book brought me back to many of my feeling and memories that I have somehow managed to suppress. The characters are so believable and the way she shifts perspectives creates a picture of how deployments affect each member of the family. She shows us how hard each of the roles is but that the easiest way through it is together. Well done Ms. Hanna.

title: Military and Civilian Lives
content: The bond, closeness and absolute meeting of the souls that Jolene and Tami have had since they were 18 and the only women in their boot camp and at Fly school. These women flew Blackhawks they were warriors, their strength far more mighty and wiser than any man’s because she’s fought 10x harder to earn respect, recognition and the acceptance of the men she’s been training with and flying with in National Guard. Jolene, a mother of Betsy 12 and Lulu 4, lives right next door to her best friend and fellow fly girl, Tami who is a mother to Seth 12. These mothers are called to serve in Iraq shortly after 9/11. Their tour requires their service for 1 year. The atrocities, harrowing fear, unbelievable and undeniable bravery, fierce loyalty and love for the other 3 soldiers who fly with their on their missions is unwavering and inspiring. Kristin Hannah does an outstanding job of portraying the perils, graphic ugly terrifying haunting hellish moments a solidier is forced to endure every moment they are called for duty. While in Iraq these women were never safe were under fire from the minute they got off their plane and in their trailers where they sleep they are pummeled with explosions, live shelli by and while flying, these brave selfless angels if the skies are always exposed far more than any of their fellow soldiers on the ground- the author shows us the hell, the bone deep fear the soul crushing grief angst and despair that soldiers in war exposed to. Their anxiety is continuous and immense the fear of dying or a fellow soldier dying is all encompassing. These women prepared their family’s for their departure and how to cope without them. Yet bo one had told these women how to cope while there or when they got home. I very much loved this especially because women were the main characters and soldiers and flew Black Hawks fighting valiantly and far braver than any of us can ever imagine or do. The lack of resources and help for our vets, the very real PTSD most will have while coming back from war and they’re not given the very best and should have a myriad of resources and support not to mention to earn far more higher wages they give their lives, their mental health and sacrifice far more than the time spent in act duty- they give all of themselves to this country to our safety and freedom and they should be given an exorbitant amount of support money and respect than they ever receive. I appreciate that. Ms Hannah she’d a spotlight on these causes and very real issues that are affecting soldiers who’ve seen combat and hopefully they will be given these resources and recognition and rehabilitation for all their soldiers every need when they are back stateside. They certainly have earned that and far more.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 13, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I am a veteran myself. So it definitely intrigued me to read this story. Before this I read The women. Unfortunately, it left much to be desired. I struggled to form much connection to the characters. There was the constant show and not tell. “In no time” was used excessively at the end of the book. And I simply could not get over how obnoxious Betsy was. No emotional connection or understanding how this character was always seen as the victim and never reprimanded for her nasty attitude. Can’t imagine a women as strong as Jolene, who is also a soldier, allowing that kind of attitude in her home.

title: What a page turner!
content: It is hard to read Kristin Hannah’s books and not be changed by them. Reading both “Home Front” and “The Women” helped me understand how difficult reentry is for returning veterans and medics. Reading “The Four Winds” helped me understand the Dustbowl and how four years of drought impacted so many lives. And reading “The Nightingale” helped me understand the many roles women played in fighting for peace during WWII. Most of all I learned to appreciate the author’s strong female protagonists who are forever forging their way and breaking barriers to survive. Love this author!

title: Excellent story of a wife/mother who is also a Blackhawk pilot who goes to the battle field.
content: Excellent read of a woman who loves her country and loves being a Blackhawk pilot. Loves her family and being a wife/mother.  Strives to balance and be the best at home and career.  A husband who doesn't understand her motivation and the military.  A realistic story line of a family coping with a parent leaving for the battle field. Only this time it is the wife/mother who goes. How miscommunication and feelings are affected.  How PTSD can and does tear apart a family apart. Joleen, the main character is a woman who struggles with her love of flying versus her love of family.  Her guilt of leaving her 2 young daughters.  I rated this a 5 Star as once I started reading I  could not put the book down.  The author did wonderful research on the military, making this story authentic and realistic.  First time reading this author and I will look forward to reading more of her books.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Jolene is a Black Hawk helicopter pilot, who is married to Michael, a defense attorney. They have two daughters, 12 year-old Betsy and 4 year-old Lulu. Jolene is very dedicated to her family but is also dedicated to her role as a pilot. Her next door neighbor and best friend, Tami, is also a pilot. They trained together and fly together.

title: Hard Hitting
content: Michael is anti war and doesn’t like his wife’s military job. He is dedicated to his job defending alleged criminals and leaves the bulk of the parenting and running of the house to Jolene. Michael has taken on the defense of Keith Keller a marine who was accused ok killing his wife.  Keith admitted to Michael that he committed the crime and couldn’t understand why Michael was defending him. Research showed that Keith had done two tours of Iraq and was suffering from PTSD, which became Michael’s defense.

title: Verified Purchase
content: When Jolene and Tami are deployed to Iraq, Michael was angry that she had to be involved in a war he did not believe in. Their marriage appeared to be on the rocks, but in Jolene’s absence he had take on the role of full time parent, something he no experience in. As Michael struggled with his new role, Jolene was heavily involved in combat zones in Iraq. Michael was still working his PTSD defense case and gained a much better understanding of the effects of war on members of the military.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2013

title: Wow, outstanding!
content: Would Jolene return unscathed from her deployment? Will she return at all?
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 12, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: The author pulls no punches in describing the effects of war and PTSD and also the effects it has on families of those affected. It will certainly give readers a greater understanding of the devastation it can have on military personnel and their families. It is recommended reading.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 3, 2024

title: It's hard to come back home...
content: I thought The Women was great, but this is right up next to it. It gives a great description of the true cost of war intertwined with individuals and their emotions, on the surface and in the mind. It’s a romance story and so much more. Having been a mentor for wounded and caregivers at WR and Bethesda NNMC, for 20 years, I totally endorse this wonderful book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 23, 2012

title: Verified Purchase
content: Summary: Michael and Jolene's marriage is falling apart--they are not even sure they love each other anymore. Add to that a 12 year old moody almost teenager, and a 4 year old who likes to play kitten.  Oh let's not forget that Jolene is a pilot for the Army National Guard unit, and they are deploying. Deployment and homecoming throw this family through changes and realizations that will break and mend your heart in a very meaningful way.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 28, 2024

title: Great read!
content: Review: I am not a crier. I don't cry during movies, weddings, or even when my own husband deploys. I don't cry during a book. But I did cry in more than one place through this book by Kristin Hannah.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 10, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I received mixed feedback for this book. I think a major problem a lot of people have is that a (military) family is not supposed to act this way! But I think focusing on that is missing the point entirely.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 30, 2024
